reporting-org.narrative: Trust for Indigenous Culture and Health

title.narrative: Building the Capacity of civil Society and communities to address SRHR in Kenya

description.narrative: Strengthening capacity of SRHR civil society organisations, CBOs and individual activists to develop long term harmonised strategies to monitor and address opposition groups by March 2022.

activity-date.narrative: This is the planned start date

organisation.narrative: Trust for Indigenous Culture and Health

job-title.narrative: Monitoring Evaluation Learning and Sharing (MELS) Coordinator

recipient-country.narrative: The project is being implemented in Kenya

description.narrative: A concept note and agenda developed for the digital security training targeting RRT members who missed out in the previous training. The training is planned to be conducted virtually due to COVID restrictions.

title.narrative: 20 CSO & CBOs trained in Strategy Development
Number of non-traditional allies partnered with (Religious leaders)

description.narrative: A concept note and agenda was developed to train 30 religious leaders who were mobilised and the training was set for 30th to 31st March. However, due to the surge of COVID 19 new guidelines were issued that prohibited physical meetings and since this would not be practical with the religious leaders we are exploring an alternative working strategy.

title.narrative: A least 40 religious leaders champions SRHR
Strengthened Collaboration among CSOs in delivering joint strategies

description.narrative: A joint meeting with a selected committee which aimed to : (1.) Finalise the draft advocacy strategy in in advancing SRHR issues in Kenya. (2.) Develop an action plan for joint and collaborative advancing of SRHR issues

title.narrative: New joint advocacy campaigns planned and implemented together with other CSOs

description.narrative:
We completed and launched the strategy on advancement of SRHR in Kenya with clear action plan for implementation.
23 Committee members were appraised on emerging security threats in relation to advancing SRHR issues.

title.narrative: Duty Bearers at National and County Governments implment supportive SHRHR laws, policies and court oders

description.narrative: Following the training of journalists last quarter, we selected 6 of the journalists and sponsored them to write stories on SRHR.

title.narrative: We love our children just the way they are by Faith Oneya (Nation Media Group)

description.narrative: This was one of the article published by the editors we engaged during the reporting period

title.narrative: Increased Media coverage of SRHR from a Human Rights perspective

description.narrative: Number of media personnel (Journalist and editors) training workshops on positive SRHR reporting working with at least 25 Journalists and 10 Editors

title.narrative: Improved collaboration of like minded CSOs, CBOs, activists and non traditional allies at National and County Level

description.narrative: Nakuru based RRT member RHYFE reported attacks from opposition members. The attacks started off as verbal then escalated to physical attacks. The RRT member reached out to us seeking guidance on how to better protect themselves, their office and staff

title.narrative: Long term harmonised locally developed strategy developed and successfully implemented

description.narrative: Following the report, we reached out to our physical security consultant. She advised that the first step would be to conduct a physical security assessment of the RHYFE office as well as have a briefing session with the RRT member. We conducted the physical security assessment and will implement some of the recommendations from the assessment in the coming quarter.

title.narrative: CSOs group support 1 public interest case

description.narrative: On March 5th, we held a meeting with the strategic litigation team at KELIN. The aim of the meeting was to identify cases that KELIN and the larger RRT can take up on that speak to our objectives. As a result of the meeting, we identified two cases that the team will take forward.

title.narrative: Number of public interest litigation cases taken to court by CSOs goups working on safe abortion and CSE
Strengthened Collaboration among CSOs in delivering joint strategies

description.narrative:
The objective of the security management training included: (1) Appraise the participants on the on-going SRHR landscape. (2) to empower the participants on organisation assessment of threats, risks and capacity. (3). Design joint key principles and actions on security management among CSOs.
The sessions covered: 1. Environmental security analysis, 2. Stakeholder analysis and introduction to safety and security ( understanding vulnerabilities risks, threats and capacities). 3. Trauma and Psychosocial well-being. 4 Digital safety and security considerations within the SRHR network and organisations. 5. Designing minimum security protocol standards.

title.narrative: Number of CSOs & CBOs trained in strategy development for legal, communication & Security

description.narrative: An action planned designed for what the committee with start to do, what they with keep doing and what they should stop doing. TICAH to undertake risk assessment for organisations within the network. TICAH and KELIN to plan specific trainings for the various aspects of security.

title.narrative: Number of mainstream media articles, TV shows positively reporting about Abortion and CSE

description.narrative: The opinion editorials were sent to editors of Nation Media Group and People Daily. The first editorial titled Ministerial directives will not cure pregnancies; We need sexuality education in schools, not imperial edicts and a second editorial on human rights and how Geneva Consensus Declaration undermines these rights

title.narrative: 3 main stream media articles
Harmonized advocacy messaging products developed (IEC, Videos, animations) and disseminated through mainstream and social media

description.narrative: The out put has three clearly stated indicators as; number of mainstream media articles, TV shows positively reporting about abortion and CSE, Compelling social media campaigns on safe abortion and CSE running at least one each quarter and Number of women rights groups engaged in collective advocacy and active monitoring and addressing of opposition during ICPD+25 conference

title.narrative: Number of women rights groups engaged collective and in active monitoring and dressing of opposition during ICPD+25 conference

description.narrative: As a contribution to this indicator, during the ICPD+25 KELIN and TICAH hosted three Women rights Organizations breakfast meetings to facilitate a safe space strategy building and share specific opposition monitoring intelligence between and among national, regional and global sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) advocates attending the ICPD25 Nairobi Summit. As a result, three committees were created a) Opposition Monitoring – This group was in charge of following the counter summit commitments and tracking. b) State Mapping – This group was to monitor State commitments and pledges towards progress on any of the twelve objectives information shared there so at to inform the week’s and future advocacy efforts. c) Media and Communications – That was in charge of generating progressive statements, crafting social media messages and coordinating media opportunities. KEY FINDINDS FROM ICPD+25 COMMITTEES Opposition Monitoring Findings:- the committee kept a brace on what was happening towards opposing ICPD+25 conference and mitigated through right messaging and packaging information about the values the conference tended to achieve. State Mapping – Built participants knowledge and ongoing efforts to track progressive States statements and amplify these on social media as well as tracking retrogressive positions by various States. Safety and security – Through the creation of a WhatsApp group, there was an opportunity to keep abreast with any security threats and share among participants. The group on media and communication developed a social media strategy and used hashtag #Kenyans4ICPD to increase conversations around ICPD+25. Additionally, the space promoted diversity of messaging of social media for greater solidarity across movements this included with LGBTQI and disability groups

title.narrative: Strengthened Collaboration among CSOs in delivering joint strategies

description.narrative: This out-put targets to ensure that at least 20 CSOs & CBOs trained on legal, communication and security strategies

title.narrative: Undertake a three-day security training for the cohort of 20 CSOs & staff members from TICAH and KELIN to enhance understanding of holistic security exposure

description.narrative: During this period we conducted physical security assessment for 6 CSOs . Based on the results from the assessment TICAH was trained on digital and physical security.

comment.narrative: There was delay in the development of the strategies due to COVID 19 pandemic. However, organisations went ahead and conducted virtual meetings and trainings

title.narrative: Harmonized advocacy messaging products developed (IEC, Videos, animation) and disseminated through mainstream and social media

description.narrative: This output puts focus on increasing information, creating awareness and advocating for sexual reproductive health rights (SRHR). During the reporting period we ran twitter chats that was emphasized on positive messaging on social media. We were also able to develop social media posters that were then shared and generated discussions around SRHR

title.narrative: Number of mainstream media articles, TV shows positively reporting about CSE

description.narrative: We engaged 4 national and community radio stations on discussions around CSE. In various radio stations we supported Radio shows that increased access to information and created awareness on CSE

title.narrative: Compelling social media campaigns on safe abortion and CSE running at least one each quarter

description.narrative: We have ran campaigns on twitter and social media to increase awareness and information of CSE. twitter handles #ifonlyIknew and #whatIwishIknew were used to engage partners and relevant stakeholders to discuss CSE

title.narrative: Strengthened Collaboration among CSOs in delivering joint strategies

description.narrative:
To realise this output some of the activities that were planned were to convene a 23 member Project Steering Committee that includes community mobilisers that meets quarterly to ensure consistent monitoring of work and progress in the project the quarter. During this period a rapid response team was created that consists of organisations that implement SRHR and has the resources and capacity to support progress monitoring.
We developed a Theory of Change in advancing sexual reproductive rights through multi-stakeholder approach.

title.narrative: Strengthened capacities and partnerships Religious Leaders

description.narrative:
A rapid response team was created and a TOR developed for the team that will be meeting quarterly to deliberate on work and progress of the project
Training conducted for 20 (with a gender ration of 13 Female and 7 Male)religious leaders from the different Counties in Kenya and aimed at strengthening their capacity and knowledge on Sexual Reproductive Health Rights. The specific objectives of the training included: (1.) Increase knowledge levels among the leaders on SRHR. (2.) Strengthened partnerships between religious institutions and SRHR CSOs (3.) Awareness creation on SRHR legal and policy environment in Kenya. Further, the training included Comprehensive Sexual Education, Adolescents sexual reproductive health rights, awareness on national guideline on management of SGBV and values clarification on SRHR

title.narrative: Successful engagement with Ministry of health at both the County and National levels

description.narrative: We had a planning meeting with Nakuru County MOH that was chaired by County health committee with other county leaders present. the meeting was held in order to plan for activities based on Nakuru MNCH bill to be complemented in the legislative process. The meeting was attended by health committee chairman-County assembly and 4 partners from CSOs . The meeting was able to identify key enablers and opposition to the bill and developed key action points on how to ensure the bill be reintroduced with minor challenges.

title.narrative: Number of engagements with the Ministry of Health at both the National and County level

description.narrative: We were able to engage key stakeholders including the MOH at the county level and we rallied their support for the bill to be passed and agreed on workable strategies.

title.narrative: Harmonised messaging products developed (IEC, Videos, animation) and disseminated through mainstream and social media

description.narrative: We had a session with 15 CSOs on developing key messages and shared ideas on different strategies the participating organisations used to talk about their advocacy work . In addition we held a session with 20 youth SRHR champions to understand misinformation around SRHR issues and what responses would help address the misconceptions. A community meeting with 20 participants was also held to deliberate of what IEC materials would be effective at the community level. Some of the IEC materials and strategies suggested by the community members were: (1) Branding the exercise books cover page with SRHR information to reach adolescents and young people at school. (2) Branding; Wrist bands, t-shirts, Leso, scarfs, pamphlets and reflector for boda boda riders. (3) Hosting SRHR campaign functions like football tournaments, talent shows and open forums. (4) Community radio talk shows . (5) Digital SRHR campaigns using digital platforms

title.narrative: Workshop to develop messages held
Compelling social media campaigns

description.narrative: We had a twitter campaign that was intended to inform ongoing conversations following the rescinding of the global gag rule by the new President of United States Joe Biden. Our second twitter chat titled #EndFemicideKe was informed by the increasing cases of femicide across the country

title.narrative: at least 2 social media campaigns
1 training with 25 journalists

description.narrative: We have worked with RRT members to map out journalists who are pro-SRHR. We also reached out to the Association of Media Women in Kenya (AMWIK) who already conduct trainings for journalists on SRHR to collaborate with us on this activity. Their response to our collaboration request was positive and we are looking to host a training for atleast 25 journalists by end of May 2021.

title.narrative: Number of mainstream media articles, TV shows positively reporting about Abortion and CSE
Long term harmonised locally developed strategy and successfully implemented

description.narrative: We held a meeting with the RRT to discuss and review the security strategy and discussed future plans for implementation. The document has received in-puts for revision which are being incorporated in strengthening the monitoring strategy .

title.narrative: Long term harmonised locally developed strategy and successfully implemented
Improved collaboration of like minded CSOs, CBOs, activists and non traditional allies at National and County Level

description.narrative: We held sensitisation forums for civil society representatives working on SRHR in Kisumu and Nakuru Counties. The sensitisation forums were a precursor to meetings for engagement with MOH officials.

title.narrative: Strengthened Collaboration among CSOs in delivering joint strategies

description.narrative:
On Number of CSOs & CBOs trained in strategy development for legal, communication & Security, we engaged CSOs and by engaging the CSOs we were able to get a contextualised understanding of SRHR opposition and interventions they had developed to counter them. This helped to inform our conversations with county officials as we had a better understanding of the issues affecting the CSOs in those counties. The aim of the meetings in the two counties were as follows: Sensitise CSO representatives from the two counties on opposition trends and tactics. To build a wealth of knowledge on opposition trends and tactics in both counties and mitigation measures.
In Nakuru, we engaged 20 SRHR activists while in Kisumu we engaged 17 CSO representatives.

title.narrative: Increased Media coverage of SRHR from a Human Rights perspective

description.narrative: We intended to achieve this output by ensuring regular media engagements to hold duty bearers accountable (Op Eds, open letters, petitions, TV slots, Press releases) including social media engagement.

title.narrative: Increased media coverage of SRHR demonstrating accurate and holistic understanding of SRHR topics from a Human Rights Perspective

description.narrative: During the reporting period we ran campaigns on twitter and facebook about the international day for safe abortion and September 28th on action against unsafe abortion. We also reviewed the petition with a representative from the parliament in readiness for questioning in the parliament. Additionally, we participated in the campaign with the white ribbon alliance.

title.narrative: Number of successful petitions presented to Ministry of Health on policies or laws not implemented by the respective bodies

description.narrative: We worked with Youth Empowerment Movement, an RRT member to mobilise signatures for the petition. Our target was to collect 5000 signatures by 7th April. Today the petition has collected 6035 signatures. Femicide in particular has become very rampant with reports from the Kenya National Bureau of Statistics reporting a record 26 cases in the first 3 months of 2021. In response to this, and as people who work directly for and with women, we organized a petition on change.org (https://www.change.org/p/kenyan-government-not-on-my-watch-stop-the-killing-of-our-women-and-girls )

title.narrative: Number of successful petitions presented to Ministry of Health on policies or laws not implemented by the respective bodies
Increased Media coverage of SRHR from a Human Rights perspective

description.narrative: this outputted targeted to ensure Regular media engagements to hold duty bearers accountable (Op Eds, open letters, petitions, TV slots, Press releases) including social media engagement

title.narrative: Increased media coverage of SRHR demonstrating accurate and holistic understanding of SRHR topics from a Human Rights Perspective
